item.title: Binary
item.description: #course_cs50 base-2 Our everyday number system is a decimal-based (i.e. base-10) one. Take the number 123 for example, we can think of this as 1 in the 100s slot, 2 in the 10s slot, 3 in the 1s slot; adding them we get 123 Generalising this, each of those slots is 10 to the power of something: $100 = 10^2, 10 = 10^1, 1 = 10^0$ If we wanted to switch to a binary system, i.
